Facebook is facing a fine of over $650,000 in Britain after the country’s information regulator said Wednesday the company failed to protect millions of users’ data.
Britain’s Information Commissioner Elizabeth Denham said she intends to fine Facebook 500,000 pounds ($663,850), the maximum amount allowed, Reuters reported.
Denham claims Facebook broke the law by not being able to protect people’s information and hadn’t been open about how data was harvested from their platform.
“Facebook has failed to provide the protections required under data protection laws,” Denham told reporters before the announcement, according to Politico.
“New technologies that use data analytics to micro-target people give campaign groups the ability to connect with individual voters.
But this cannot be at the expense of transparency, fairness and compliance with the law,” she said in a statement.
